Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the father needs to provide it
Expectation2: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation2: They wear gloves occasionally when handling certain cleaning tasks.
Story:
I stared at the crumpled bills in my wallet, counting them for the third time. My daughter’s school fees were due, and the fridge was nearly empty. As a father, I felt the weight of every expectation—my family needed me to keep us afloat, to make sure there was food on the table and a roof over our heads. That’s why I took every extra shift I could get as a housekeeping cleaner at the hotel, even when my body ached from exhaustion.

Today, the supervisor reminded us again: gloves must be worn for all cleaning tasks, no exceptions. But the supply room was running low, and the manager hinted that if we used too many, it might come out of our pay. I hesitated, glancing at the dirty bathroom I was assigned to clean. If I skipped the gloves, I could finish faster, maybe squeeze in another room, earn a little more. But the risk of getting sick—and bringing something home—gnawed at me. My mind spun between the need to provide for my family and the rules I was supposed to follow. I stood there, gloves in hand, torn between what I had to do and what I was supposed to do.
